fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let A_{1} and A_{2} be two subobjects of A in a Heyting category. Then the Heyting implication A_{1} \Rightarrow A_{2} exists. Moreover, for any morphism f\colon B\to A, f^{*}(A_{1} \Rightarrow A_{2}) \cong f^{*}(A_{1}) \Rightarrow f^{*}(A_{2}) in \mathsf {Sub}(B).

Fix a subobject m\colon A_{1}\rightarrowtail A. Recall from that A_{1} \cap (\mathord {\hspace {1pt}\text {--}\hspace {1pt}}) may be described as \exists _{m}m^{*}. Then take A_{1} \Rightarrow (\mathord {\hspace {1pt}\text {--}\hspace {1pt}}) to be the right adjoint of A_{1} \cap (\mathord {\hspace {1pt}\text {--}\hspace {1pt}}) given as follows:

Then for any subobject A_{2} \in \mathsf {Sub}(A) the counit of the adjunction \varepsilon _{A_{2}}\colon A_{1} \cap (A_{1} \Rightarrow A_{2})\to A_{2} says precisely that A_{1} \cap (A_{1} \Rightarrow A_{2}) is contained in A_{2}. And A_{1} \Rightarrow A_{2} is the largest such subobject by the universal property of right adjoint.
Let f\colon B\to A be a morphism. Form the following pullback.

fr:resource.fr:resource-source: \DiagramSquare { nw = {f^{*}(A_{1})}, nw/style = {pullback}, ne = {A_{1}}, sw = B, se = A, north = g, east = m, east/style = {>->}, south = f, west = {n}, west/style = {>->}, }

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Then by Beck-Chevalley condition we have
fr:mainmatter.fr:tex: \begin {aligned} f^{*}(A_{1} \Rightarrow A_{2}) &:= f^{*}\forall _{m}m^{*}(A_{2})\\ &\cong \forall _{n}g^{*}m^{*}(A_{2}) && \text {since $mg = fn$}\\ &\cong \forall _{n}n^{*}f^{*}(A_{2})\\ &=: f^{*}(A_{1}) \Rightarrow f^{*}(A_{2}) \end {aligned}

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: A coherent category \mathcal {C} is a Heyting category if for every morphism f\colon A\to B of \mathcal {C}, the pullback functor f^{*}\colon \mathsf {Sub}(B)\to \mathsf {Sub}(A) admits a right adjoint \forall _{f}\colon \mathsf {Sub}(A)\to \mathsf {Sub}(B). A Heyting functor between Heyting categories is a coherent functor such that for any morphism f\colon A\to B and any subobject m\colon A'\rightarrowtail A, F\forall _{f}(m) \cong \forall _{Ff}(Fm) in \mathsf {Sub}(FB). Note that this definition makes sense since coherent functors preserve monomorphisms.
Let \mathcal {C} be a Heyting category and the following square be a pullback in \mathcal {C}.

fr:resource.fr:resource-source: \DiagramSquare { nw = A, nw/style = {pullback}, ne = B, sw = C, se = D, north = h, south = g, west = k, east = f, }

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Then the following square commutes up to isomorphism.

fr:resource.fr:resource-source: \DiagramSquare { nw = {\mathsf {Sub}(B)}, ne = {\mathsf {Sub}(A)}, sw = {\mathsf {Sub}(D)}, se = {\mathsf {Sub}(C)}, north = {h^{*}}, west = {\forall _{f}}, south = {g^{*}}, east = {\forall _{k}}, }

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Consider the corresponding left adjoint square.

fr:resource.fr:resource-source: \DiagramSquare { nw = {\mathsf {Sub}(B)}, ne = {\mathsf {Sub}(A)}, sw = {\mathsf {Sub}(D)}, se = {\mathsf {Sub}(C)}, north = {\exists _{h}}, north/style = {<-}, west = {f^{*}}, west/style = {<-}, south = {\exists _{g}}, south/style = {<-}, east = {k^{*}}, east/style = {<-}, }

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: By , the two composites can be constructed as f^{*}\mathsf {Img}\Sigma _{g} and \mathsf {Img}\Sigma _{h}k^{*} respectively. Since images commute with pullbacks in a regular category, we have f^{*}\mathsf {Img}\Sigma _{g} \cong \mathsf {Img}f^{*}\Sigma _{g}. Then by the pasting lemma, f^{*}\Sigma _{g}(m) \cong \Sigma _{h}k^{*}(m) for any subobject m \in \mathsf {Sub}(C), which assembles into a natural isomorphism f^{*}\Sigma _{g} \cong \Sigma _{h}k^{*}.
Thus, we can extend this natural isomorphism as follows:
Then both \forall _{k}h^{*} and g^{*}\forall _{f} are right adjoint to f^{*}\exists _{g}, so \forall _{k}h^{*} \cong g^{*}\forall _{f} by the uniqueness of adjoint.
Let A_{1} and A_{2} be two subobjects of A. The Heyting implication A_{1} \Rightarrow A_{2} is the largest subobject of A such that A_{1} \cap (A_{1} \Rightarrow A_{2}) is contained in A_{2}.

Let A_{1} and A_{2} be two subobjects of A in a Heyting category. Then the Heyting implication A_{1} \Rightarrow A_{2} exists. Moreover, for any morphism f\colon B\to A, f^{*}(A_{1} \Rightarrow A_{2}) \cong f^{*}(A_{1}) \Rightarrow f^{*}(A_{2}) in \mathsf {Sub}(B).

Fix a subobject m\colon A_{1}\rightarrowtail A. Recall from that A_{1} \cap (\mathord {\hspace {1pt}\text {--}\hspace {1pt}}) may be described as \exists _{m}m^{*}. Then take A_{1} \Rightarrow (\mathord {\hspace {1pt}\text {--}\hspace {1pt}}) to be the right adjoint of A_{1} \cap (\mathord {\hspace {1pt}\text {--}\hspace {1pt}}) given as follows:

Then for any subobject A_{2} \in \mathsf {Sub}(A) the counit of the adjunction \varepsilon _{A_{2}}\colon A_{1} \cap (A_{1} \Rightarrow A_{2})\to A_{2} says precisely that A_{1} \cap (A_{1} \Rightarrow A_{2}) is contained in A_{2}. And A_{1} \Rightarrow A_{2} is the largest such subobject by the universal property of right adjoint.
Let f\colon B\to A be a morphism. Form the following pullback.

fr:resource.fr:resource-source: \DiagramSquare { nw = {f^{*}(A_{1})}, nw/style = {pullback}, ne = {A_{1}}, sw = B, se = A, north = g, east = m, east/style = {>->}, south = f, west = {n}, west/style = {>->}, }

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Then by Beck-Chevalley condition we have
fr:mainmatter.fr:tex: \begin {aligned} f^{*}(A_{1} \Rightarrow A_{2}) &:= f^{*}\forall _{m}m^{*}(A_{2})\\ &\cong \forall _{n}g^{*}m^{*}(A_{2}) && \text {since $mg = fn$}\\ &\cong \forall _{n}n^{*}f^{*}(A_{2})\\ &=: f^{*}(A_{1}) \Rightarrow f^{*}(A_{2}) \end {aligned}

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \mathcal {C} be a Heyting category and the following square be a pullback in \mathcal {C}.

fr:resource.fr:resource-source: \DiagramSquare { nw = A, nw/style = {pullback}, ne = B, sw = C, se = D, north = h, south = g, west = k, east = f, }

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Then the following square commutes up to isomorphism.

fr:resource.fr:resource-source: \DiagramSquare { nw = {\mathsf {Sub}(B)}, ne = {\mathsf {Sub}(A)}, sw = {\mathsf {Sub}(D)}, se = {\mathsf {Sub}(C)}, north = {h^{*}}, west = {\forall _{f}}, south = {g^{*}}, east = {\forall _{k}}, }

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Consider the corresponding left adjoint square.

fr:resource.fr:resource-source: \DiagramSquare { nw = {\mathsf {Sub}(B)}, ne = {\mathsf {Sub}(A)}, sw = {\mathsf {Sub}(D)}, se = {\mathsf {Sub}(C)}, north = {\exists _{h}}, north/style = {<-}, west = {f^{*}}, west/style = {<-}, south = {\exists _{g}}, south/style = {<-}, east = {k^{*}}, east/style = {<-}, }

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: By , the two composites can be constructed as f^{*}\mathsf {Img}\Sigma _{g} and \mathsf {Img}\Sigma _{h}k^{*} respectively. Since images commute with pullbacks in a regular category, we have f^{*}\mathsf {Img}\Sigma _{g} \cong \mathsf {Img}f^{*}\Sigma _{g}. Then by the pasting lemma, f^{*}\Sigma _{g}(m) \cong \Sigma _{h}k^{*}(m) for any subobject m \in \mathsf {Sub}(C), which assembles into a natural isomorphism f^{*}\Sigma _{g} \cong \Sigma _{h}k^{*}.
Thus, we can extend this natural isomorphism as follows:
Then both \forall _{k}h^{*} and g^{*}\forall _{f} are right adjoint to f^{*}\exists _{g}, so \forall _{k}h^{*} \cong g^{*}\forall _{f} by the uniqueness of adjoint.
Let A_{1} and A_{2} be two subobjects of A. The Heyting implication A_{1} \Rightarrow A_{2} is the largest subobject of A such that A_{1} \cap (A_{1} \Rightarrow A_{2}) is contained in A_{2}.

A coherent category \mathcal {C} is a Heyting category if for every morphism f\colon A\to B of \mathcal {C}, the pullback functor f^{*}\colon \mathsf {Sub}(B)\to \mathsf {Sub}(A) admits a right adjoint \forall _{f}\colon \mathsf {Sub}(A)\to \mathsf {Sub}(B). A Heyting functor between Heyting categories is a coherent functor such that for any morphism f\colon A\to B and any subobject m\colon A'\rightarrowtail A, F\forall _{f}(m) \cong \forall _{Ff}(Fm) in \mathsf {Sub}(FB). Note that this definition makes sense since coherent functors preserve monomorphisms.
Let \mathcal {C} be a coherent category. Then intersections distribute over unions, i.e., for any three subobjects A_{1}, A_{2}, and A_{3} of A, the following holds.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: Let m\colon A_{1}\rightarrowtail A be a subobject of \mathcal {C}. Then by , A_{1} \cap (\mathord {\hspace {1pt}\text {--}\hspace {1pt}}) can be described as the composite \mathsf {Sub}(A) \xrightarrow {m^{*}} \mathsf {Sub}(A_{1}) \xrightarrow {\exists _{m}} \mathsf {Sub}(A). Thus, we have

fr:mainmatter.fr:tex: \begin {align*} A_{1} \cap (A_{2} \cup A_{3}) &\cong \exists _{m}m^{*}(A_{2} \cup A_{3}) && \text {$m^{*}$ preserves finite unions}\\ &\cong \exists _{m}(m^{*}(A_{2}) \cup m^{*}(A_{3})) && \text {left adjoint preserves finite unions}\\ &\cong \exists _{m}m^{*}(A_{2}) \cup \exists _{m}m^{*}(A_{3})\\ &\cong (A_{1} \cap A_{2}) \cup (A_{1} \cap A_{3}) \end {align*}
